THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES

J. D. MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.

SUNDAY CHURCH SERVICES

St. Mary's
St. John's
St. Paul's
St. Andrew's
St. Peter's
St. James'

FRIDAY, MAY 28, 1886.

The Edmonton Bulletin of the day makes mention of Inspector Hackett's report to Sag Harbour and Prince Albert. It seems that Inspector Hackett has been working hard during the recent troubles in Sag Harbour and Prince Albert. It is true that he does not seem to have much influence at present, but there is no doubt that he will be coming back soon. Meanwhile, we must make do without his services. Delay is dangerous.

A bill has passed the U.S. Senate authorizing the President to issue proclamation allowing the United States to enter into treaties with foreign countries as are desired by the United States. This will allow the United States to enter into treaties with foreign countries as desired by the United States, and will result in the establishment of American ports and the revitalization of American vessels.

Now that the government has taken steps to establish a supreme court in the Northwest, it is expected that the government will be able to settle the disputes between the various nations. The government has been working hard to bring about peace and prosperity in the Northwest, and it is hoped that the new supreme court will be able to help achieve these goals.

THE MEDICINE HAT LUMBER COY.

W. T. FINLAY, Manager.

QUEEN'S BIRTHDAY

May 26th, 1879

The Queen's Birthday was celebrated in Prince Albert Park, London, on May 26th, 1879. The weather was fine, and the day was spent in outdoor activities. At about noon, a large crowd gathered at the park, and a band played music. The Queen appeared on a balcony overlooking the park, and the crowd cheered. Afternoon events included cricket matches, races, and a parade.

The cricket matches were played between the Argyle and Mission clubs, and the Argyle club won. The races included a horse race, a dog race, and a bicycle race. The bicycle race was won by a member of the Mission club.

The parade featured floats and bands, and the Queen presented prizes to the winners of the races and matches.

The day ended with fireworks, and the Queen returned to Buckingham Palace.
